App description:
VARK is a live concert venue platform for virtual artists.
Virtual artists, or VTubers, is a rising movement of online artists and influencers who express themselves using real-time motion captured avatars. They are exploding in popularity through video sites and social media, especially in Japan and other Asian countries.
With VARK, virtual artist fans can go see their favorite artists perform shows, up close and personal in VR. Sounds like your cup of tea? Come on in!

* A virtual concert experience with stage effects impossible in real life
* Motion-captured virtual artists sing, dance and talk right before your eyes
* Audience participation through messages, gifts and more!

The virtual artist revolution is on - here at VARK!

# Notice:
* You must purchase digital tickets to participate in an event, much like how a real life concert requires tickets.
* Since most concerts are performed live, you can only participate when a show is on. Check the app for show schedules.
Purchase section: FreeAdd to WishlistShareOffers In-App PurchasesComfortableSupports QuestSupports Oculus TouchInternet connection required

ABucketMay 14 at 1:47 PM
Pretty niche, but well-done

You need to have certain interests to like this. Are you interested in Japanese? Do you like anime characters/vtubers? Would you pay money for a virtual concert where the performer has a little interaction with the audience but have no idea what theyre saying?

For me, I can check all of those boxes. There was a free concert in March that would make me decide whether I keep this or not. I attended and had a blast! I really hope they have more free concerts to give people a better taste on what Vark has to offer. Are the tickets expensive? Yeah, a bit. Im looking at a 3 concert pack for about $120 cad. You can toss bouquets onto the stage but like theyre $5-10 each. But this is also supporting a creator who I assume wrote the songs or at least spent a lot of time practicing. They design how the lights shine like an actual concert. Me personally, Im willing to pay those ticket prices because I think its worth it, but you have to make that decision yourself

DerpyEagleFeb 4 at 8:10 PM
Spend your money elsewhere.

I'm a simple man; I saw Hatsune Miku in the preview trailer for this app and downloaded it immediately.

I saw all the one-star reviews. I realised that I'd have to buy virtual tickets to attend these concerts, but this was okay with me. I'd love to support the artists that I listen to and the VTubers that I watch. One of the benefits of holding concerts in VR is that without the cost of a traditional venue, pricing can be far, far lower than a physical concert, allowing for much cheaper ticket costs. Come on, how much could a virtual ticket cost-- $5? $10? I assumed that most of the one-star reviews were just people that felt misled by the app's "free" price on the store, a position that is valid but didn't stop me from wanting to try it out myself.

In the app, I went to see how much the next Miku concert would cost me. There's no scheduled programming for 2020, so to find the price to expect, I went to the last concert that had Miku in it.
When I saw that it had cost just under $70 CAD, I'm pretty sure I coughed up a little blood. I scrolled through the list of other events in abject horror, realizing that this wasn't even the most expensive event. There were ones that were cheaper, but I didn't see even a single event under $15.

I love Hatsune Miku (and I saw some other names I wanted to see, too), but I'm a student, and if attending these concerts and events means blowing my food budget for the month, no chance.

For those like me who are interested but can't afford this app: watch 360 vocaloid videos in VRChat with friends. Go to the MMD dance world if you want a more 3D experience; it's comparable to what this app (seems to) offer, on-demand, totally free, and has a greater degree of user customization.

Developers of this app: you are getting bad reviews because you charge way too much for tickets to each event. Even half of the price you have now would still be too much.

Developer ResponseDec 22 at 10:42 PM

Hi GlowBox, thanks for the review! Just to make sure, VARK is not a game nor an animation/music editing tool; rather, it is more like an actual concert venue, where professionally produced & staffed concerts by avatar-donning artists take place according to predetermined show schedules. Hence, much like how admission fees apply in real life concerts, we ask users to purchase tickets to join the events. We want to ensure that the performers we invite onto our platform can gain profit from the concerts they hold. Also, we have updated our app description to better communicate the cultural background; please take a look! As for the hands being stuck together in the trial concert, that doesn't seem to be our intended behavior. We will look into it.

RavnicarJan 18 at 9:06 AM
THIS IS NOT A GAME! ITS LIVE PERFORMANCE

I noticed many 1 star reviews dragging this application down and all of them seem to be confused as to what this is.
It is not a game. It is not a music viewer. This is to watch live performances from virtual singers and artists such as Hastune Miku, Kisuna Ai, and Kaf. Like a real concert, the performances have scheduled times, and you pay admission. There are some mild interaction like cheering and clapping and you can even purchase big interactions that everyone can see such as fireworks, or throwing flowers. That being said this is to watch a concert love with other people, so your mostly going to be in one spot, watching.

Personally I think this is a great application for a specific fan base. Most western audiences may not quite get the point, but for those who are familiar it even curious about virtual artists, it's a great (and kinda meta) way to experience seeing them live without having fly to Holo concert.

jmalmstenDec 4 at 11:11 AM
Yeah... Nope.

So at first glance it seems innocent enough. But you open it and is greeted by mystery meat navigation. A plethora of concerts by artists I've never heard of that is labled "closed". After fumbling around I realize it's live stream only. And because of livestreaming they are all early in the morning and somehow I was looking at events that was streamed back in april. So I stumble around some more and see that there are two events upcoming. They are sold for roughly 500 varks (yep it's a "freemium" title). Whatever the going rate for that is...

So I still gave it the benefit of a doubt. Tried the trial event. And that was... A generic jpop song. There are glow sticks in your hands sometimes when I bring them together they stick awkwardly to each other and make a clapping sound. The area is filled with barely moving black silhouettes lifelessly looping their animation and to top it all off the head tracking is limited to 3dof... motion sickness inducing 3dof. In a 3D polygonal world...

Yeah, nope. This simply is not for me. And I cannot really guess who it's for either... Because surely the jpop fanatics have better venues for these things?

It just comes off as a moneygrubbing shovelware. These platforms really need to limit these low effort freemium titles . It ruined mobile gaming and if we aren't careful they could ruin the perception of VR too.

TwomixDec 10 at 6:35 PM

A very good app for viewing VR virtual idol concerts. I think many US consumers are confused by the product hence the 1 star but how this works is essentially you buy tokens and the tokens can be redeemed to view a concert (which is live streamed). As long as you don't consume the tokens it's on your account so it doesn't get used up even if you miss the concert (unlike a real life virtual idol concert ticket which is used up whether you attended or not). And this platform allows you to view the concert from whatever view you like (no more rushing to get good seats). I can understand this may not be acceptable for some US users (which prefers to "own the content" and view the content at their own time and leisure). The price may also be a factor. $50-90 per show is the standard Japanese rate for these types of show (yes they're not cheap at all due to the preparation, design and programming involved). They typically last about 3 hours. Why are they expensive ? Because often shows involve trademark characters from various "franchises" plus the amount of work involved to bring you a wonderful and unique experience.
